I have seen some DM configs that are creating a nova-local partition on a separate disk, which is valid (but not sure why you wouldn't use the full disk in that case), so we can't assume that the only nova-local partitions would occur on the root disk.

I think here we would wrongly include that in the instances_lv size calculation below, so need to make sure the partition is on the root disk

I agree.  This is a very rare case where a user would have nova-local on its own disk but not have the nova-local partition consume the whole disk.  Suggest tracking this via a separate commit so that we can enable this code to merge now and start soak testing and regression.

Back to first comment, I should have given a concrete example. Add this to original comment for extra meaning:

I do see some drbd filesystm in drbd.pp still using the link as mountpoint, Example: '/opt/extension'. https://opendev.org/starlingx/stx-puppet/src/commit/2c76a2f0fedaba8fa11a1549a8e010b20a211c13/puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/manifests/drbd.pp#L197

Based on this section below

 $mountpoint = $::osfamily ? { 'Debian' => '/var/rootdirs/opt/conversion', default => '/opt/conversion' },

if a centos load ran this, the behaviour would be different.
 
I will wait and see what Bob thinks.

I dropped the realpath here because it's no longer needed with this change:

 $mountpoint = $::osfamily ? { 'Debian' => '/var/rootdirs/opt/conversion', default => '/opt/conversion' },
 
This was the only filesystem looking at /etc/fstab that was not attempting to mount at its real mount point (/opt/conversion vs. /var/rootdirs/opt/conversion). So was seeing issues when the add/remove would get out of sync due to other failures. /etc/fstab would have the the mount to /opt/conversion present and then this would blow up trying to unmount the realpath location of /var/rootdirs/opt/conversion because the filesystem was already mounted on /opt/conversion. This just gets all the mountpoints and checks in sync.
dont you love how puppet exec titles all need to be unique or you might not be running what you think you are running  :)
Yep... Annoying that it blows up, but now that it forced me add more context, it becomes more obvious in the logs what operation is happening. So not so bad.
Relocated here from ::platform::filesystem and optimized to support runtime removal of this filesystem. Having it in the absent case of ::platform::filesystem during lock/unlock posed problems.

Would it matter if capital letters F and I here?
Except work done here, this regex is not present: ::[a-z]*::[A-Z]
Doesn't matter, but fixed for consistency

lib/tempest.message:
This line jumps out to me due to the two lines above it. In particular we are taking three steps:

  707. Install tempest and all of its deps into venv-tempest using constraints
  709. Install tempest and all of its deps into venv-tempest using a possibly different constraints file
  710. Install tempest and all of its deps without a constraints file
  
Additionally, we only guard line 707 for running offline. I think this effectively means that tempest installations cannot happen during an offline run of devstack.

My suggestion for fixing this is that we figure out what the install we need/want actually is and perform that in a single line and guard that properly with the offline check.
Then I'm failing to understand while L732 tries to pick tempest from outside of the venv-tempest env.

> Then I'm failing to understand while L732 tries to pick tempest from outside of the venv-tempest env.

Because it is a different environment. The venv environment installs to .tox/venv (default envdir). The venv-tempest environment installs to .tox/tempest (overridden envdir in the tox.ini).

swift/common/db.py.message:
this sleep is one of my least favorite thing in the whole code base and all interaction with the sqlite objects goes through here - call() is still blocking

Why do we expect `locked` in the OperationalError if we already have a LockTimeout on the db_file

> this sleep is one of my least favorite thing in the whole code base

Oh yeah, it's horrible -- I hate it, too.

> Why do we expect `locked` in the OperationalError if we already have a LockTimeout on the db_file

'cause we *always* drop the timeout we pass to sqlite3 to 0 -- see the end of GreenDBConnection.__init__ -- we want sqlite3 to bomb quickly, so we can get control back out to the hub. Otherwise, *all* greenthreads are blocked on any DB operations.
is this even *reasonable* - sqlite3.Connection doesn't have any other attributes?

From https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#notes-on-using-slots

> The action of a __slots__ declaration is not limited to the class where it is defined. __slots__ declared in parents are available in child classes. However, child subclasses will get a __dict__ and __weakref__ unless they also define __slots__ (which should only contain names of any additional slots).

(It's that last bit that seems most relevant).

*BUT* ...

sqlite3.Connection doesn't actually have __slots__. So I guess this is also relevant:

> When inheriting from a class without __slots__, the __dict__ and __weakref__ attribute of the instances will always be accessible.

I think the trick is that by declaring __slots__, I force the __dict__ to be created a little more pro-actively following https://github.com/python/cpython/commit/a8b9350964f43cb648c98c179c8037fbf3ff8a7d ? IDK man.
is this even *reasonable* - sqlite3.Cursor doesn't have any other attributes?
All the stuff above about sqlite3.Connection applies to sqlite3.Cursor too.
args[0].timeout - what even is this first agrument?  the connection?
This seems suspicious as hell -- I'm amazed our tests passed before :-/
This might be necessary even once cpython fixes their bug.

Yup; even with https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/99902 to fix the segfault, I trip failures like https://paste.opendev.org/show/banhZYFaECxovH58l8FQ/ -- presumably because upstream's execute() no longer calls cursor()

Presumably we want something similar for executescript()?

> Presumably we want something similar for executescript()?

I'm less and less sure of this -- I think maybe there's not actually any expectation that executescript be greened...

If we get a KeyError exception here it would mean the "feature-gates" key isn't in the dict.

For the K8s 1.23->1.24 upgrade we expect the RemoveSelfLink feature-gate to be set, these checks are for robustness.
Regex: ,?RemoveSelfLink=false,*,?

If we have the "RemoveSelfLink=false" string in the middle of a bunch of other feature gates, we need to remove one of the commas on either side of it so that the remaining feature gates are still separated by single commas.  But we don't want to remove both commas.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Why do we set stdbuf to explicitly buffer stdout? How is this different than the default behavior? Would we lose the output if we did't buffer stderr if kubeadm is terminated early or after the timeout?

Issue with puppet is that all output (stdout, stderr) gets lost on timeout. This is upstream puppet bug without real solution.

I chose to use 'stdbuf' since the default behaviour of most programs is to buffer output, only some programs deliberately fflush at line-endings. I didn't know for sure whether stdbuf was required, possbily I could have used strace to look for flush API calls, but having this it won't hurt.
I wanted to make sure that if we hit a timeout and there's partial output hat was not flushed out, we at least get that rather than an empty partially written file.

I don't think we would lose any output in usual output or failure case, i think the timeout was really the bad behaving case.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/scripts/partition_i.message:
When the disk is an NVMe, this error will happen:

./partition_info.sh: line 56: * 512 / (1024*1024): syntax error: operand expected (error token is "* 512 / (1024*1024)")

Because it's concatenating the disk with the partition number, but when it's NVMe, there's a "p" before it.

When running the script passing the nvme disk
./partition_info.sh /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:02:00.0-nvme-1

On line:50 concatenates the disk with the partition number. That way, $device is defined as /dev/nvme0n11 instead of /dev/nvme0n1p1 as Vefa reported above.

I created a new review to fix this:
https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/config/+/866941

I am unable to test for nvme.
If I add an nvme disk  I dont get errors, but I also dont have partitions so the script doesnt report any data.
I suspect further testing on nvme might be required by Erickson

+device_path=$(realpath $1) && shift

+for device in "${device_nodes[@]}"; do

     # Parse the output and put it in the right return format.
     part_type_guid=$(sfdisk --part-type $device_path $part_number)
     part_type_name=$(echo "$sfdisk_part_info" | grep -w $device | awk '{print substr($0, index($0, $6))}' | tr ' ' '.')
@@ -55,7 +55,7 @@ for part_number in "${part_numbers[@]}"; do
     part_start_mib=$(($(echo "$sfdisk_part_info" | grep -w $device | awk '{print $2}') * $sector_size / (1024*1024)))
     part_end_mib=$((($(echo "$sfdisk_part_info" | grep -w $device | awk '{print $3}') * $sector_size / (1024*1024)) + 1))
     part_size_mib=$((part_end_mib-part_start_mib))
-    part_device_node=$(realpath $device_path)$part_number

     if [ "$part_type_name" == "unknown" ]; then
         part_type_name=$(sfdisk --part-label $device_path $part_number | tr ' ' '.')
     fi

Erickson's point is valid, because realpath will transform the /dev/disk/by-path/... path as follows:

```
$ realpath /dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:6d:00.0-nvme-1
/dev/nvme0n1
```

However, then the script will attempt to append a partition number here:

```
device="${device_path}${part_number}"
```

The correct format for NVMe includes an intermediate "p" character like the following:

```
/dev/nvme0n1p3
```
However, device_path was already converted by "realpath"...

My understanding is that the script continues to be broken for NVMe. Note that Al mentioned that he would take a look.

Just complementing.

The iqvlinux driver 1.2.0.15 is open source, and can be freely distributed, but the Quartzville tools (e.g. eeupdate64e) are proprietary from Intel.

The new patchset is based on iqvlinux driver 1.2.0.15, which is publicly available at sourceforge.net and licensed under GPL2.

As reviewed with WR Legal and WRCP Leadership teams, this is fine for including in StarlingX.

Thank you so much for your support Greg !!
In this case lets go ahead with version 1.2.0.19. I will store a new patchset.

Apologies for the confusion ...

In yesterday's meeting with WR Legal and WRCP Leadership teams,
we also discussed using the 1.2.0.19 version of the iqvlinux driver.

The source for version 1.2.0.19 of iqvlinux driver was shared with WindRiver under GPL2 license.  According to WR Legal, that is sufficient for us to use and make public in StarlingX ... REGARDLESS of whether the source for version 1.2.0.19 of iqvlinux driver is available on a public URL or not.

So use of 1.2.0.15 or 1.2.0.19 in starlingx is supported by WR Legal.

I believe the DEV team is planning on using 1.2.0.19 .

Greg has answered my concern about the expectations of our use of iqvlinux driver source.  I defer to his leg work to confirm this usage.

I do not have a strong opinion about the use of a download URL specifically for v1.2.0.19 hosted is some manner not otherwise provided by Intel, nor about the solution provided by Rogerio where he manufactures a v1.2.0.19 patch on top of v1.2.0.15 tarball.  I recognize that munging changesets into a single patch is gross.  But I am not specifically aware of a source code repository for Starlingx where the v1.2.0.19 tarball can be hosted - I searched but did not find.
Need to add the CENGN download location before this can merge
Looking forward to the removal of that 1500 line patch once version 19 can be downloaded.

I'm glad to announce that the iqvlinux driver 1.2.0.19 is now hosted in StarlingX CENGN server, so we dont need an upgrade patch anymore.

Please help to review. Thanks !
Thank you for doing the right thing and getting the source tarball hosted somewhere that the downloader can use.
I guess that last spin was to cleanup the unused "common" package.

Looks good to me in general. I have a minor comment, and a "philosophical" comment.

Thank you,

iqvlinux is an out-of-tree kernel module. Should we install it to a location where traditionally in-tree drivers are located? I suggest using lib/modules/$(kversion)/updates or lib/modules/$(kversion)/extra . Most of the out-of-tree drivers in StarlingX use the extra directory.

It is best that we just keep the same locations as the Makefile.

I am not sure if I follow.

I meant to say that you should mention this information in the commit message, so the reviewers and colleagues look who at this commit in the future will know why the in-tree kernel module directory was chosen as the installation directory.

Something like the following?

```
Note that the new kernel modules are installed to a directory where usually
only in-tree kernel modules exist. This is done to satisfy the user-space
utilities' assumptions regarding the location of the kernel module. We have
also learned that the user-space utilities' assumption regarding the kernel
module's location may change in the future.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: A quick note on this - from our testing so far, it appears that either way will work fine (ie. with our without this change).  We think it's because haproxy will be checking for a 200 response, and mark it as failed if it doesn't get it.  So it should work regardless of whether ceph dashboard responds with a 303 or a 500.
recheck

Ah ok after reading through the docs a bit more, I think the issue with leaving it as standby_behaviour=redirect is in the following situation:

1. haproxy does the health checks and determins that server A is the active server (ie. only one returning 200 response to GET /)
2. something changes in ceph and server B becomes the active server
3. user sends a request to ceph dashboard web ui, which goes through haproxy, which sends the request to server A
4. server A responds with the internal redirect and the user is redirected to the url of server B, which may not be valid externally and either way is not desirable.
5. haproxy repeats the health checks and determines that server B is now active
6. all good again

If standby_behaviour=error, in this case the user would be presented with a 500 error page at step 4, which would resolve as soon as haproxy repeats the health checks and the user refreshes the page.  This situation is much more desirable, as it is a non-confusing and easily recoverable error, rather than getting stuck on some redirected internal url.

So yep I agree we should make this change here.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I'm not sure how this case occurs. based on the error trace in the bug report, the original volume should be in backing-up state and the temporary volume in in-use state so it's not possible to delete the volume.

https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/24a783408879abd479e77dd88b43bf2a1be048fe/cinder/backup/chunkeddriver.py#L659

So looking into this in more detail, we are running Xena on 19.0 and in the temporarily volumes fix was actually backported, which I missed, and included in the 19.1.1 release [1]

What we have is a Heat stack that contains a volume and it also provisions a cron trigger in Mistral for executing a backup on the volume, if the stack is deleted and the cron trigger has triggered a backup that is currently running it will fail because the stack has deleted the volume, but the backup never enters an error state and is in creating forever (note that this is 19.0 without below[1] patch).

I actually think that it's actually possible this is solved by upgrading to 19.1.1 which would probably cause the Heat stack to enter a DELETE_FAILED state if the volume cannot be deleted when a backup has been started, I have not verified that this is solved by upgrading so I cannot confirm that's the case.

It could plausibly also be a race condition at play here but I haven't verified that to be the case. 

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1970768

Hi, sorry for my late realization, again.

I noticed that this command may output whitespace which might break parsing. Here is sample output from an Ubuntu system:

```
$ sudo sfdisk -l /dev/nvme0n1 | grep ^/dev/ | awk '{print substr($0, index($0, $6))}'
EFI System
Linux filesystem
Linux filesystem
```

Note that there is whitespace in the output.

Here is more descriptive output:
```
$ sudo sfdisk -l /dev/nvme0n1 | grep ^/dev/ | awk '{print $1, substr($0, index($0, $6))}'
/dev/nvme0n1p1 EFI System
/dev/nvme0n1p2 Linux filesystem
/dev/nvme0n1p3 Linux filesystem
```

I see that there is code in "sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/partition.py", which was removed, and whose purpose was to replace "." with " ".

I wonder if we should keep that, and replace all space characters (" ") with "." on this line.

Example:

```
part_type_name="$(echo "$sfdisk_part_info" | grep -w $device | \
   awk '{print substr($0, index($0, $6))}' | tr ' ' '.')"
```

Yes, I noticed that. However, in the condition on line 59, I added quotes around the variable so that it stays as a whole. So there is no need to replace the white space with another character and then put the white space back.

if [ "$part_type_name" == "unknown" ];

So I removed the command "tr ' ' '.'" and the ".replace('.', ' ')" in the python code.

In my tests, I had no problems.

Note the line below which reads:

```
line+="$part_number $part_device_node $part_type_guid $part_type_name $part_guid $part_start_mib $part_end_mib $part_size_mib;"
```

This line has white-space separated fields, which are then separated by semi-colons. Let's establish that.

Now, the Python code in "sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/partition.py" parses that long line, by splitting according to semicolons first, and then whitespace next.

Quoting from get_sgdisk_info method in "sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/agent/partition.py" on line 38:

```
        rows = [row for row in sgdisk_output.split(';') if row.strip()]
        for row in rows:
            values = row.split()
            partition = dict(zip(fields, values))
            if 'part_number' in partition.keys():
                partition['part_number'] = int(partition['part_number'])
            sgdisk_part_info.append(partition)
```

Note how the line is split, first according to ';', then according to whitespace.

Now, if the part_type_name has embedded whitespace, then the "values = row.split()" line above will be broken. Do you agree with that?

I think we should fix that by replacing each space character in part_type_name with '.' in this script, and then replace it back with space in the Python code so that this issue is avoided.

I understand that your tests did not encounter issues, but that does not detract from what I demonstrate above.

Regarding line 59, I think that is okay, but I would double-check that the "--part-label" option does not result in white-space as well, for line 60:

```
$ sudo sfdisk --part-label  /dev/nvme0n1 1
EFI System Partition
```

The whitespace is in the output here...

---

All this to say, please reinstate the whitespace to dot and dot to whitespace conversions. We need them.
Done

Using the last character as the partition number will not work when there are more than 9 partitions. The suggested code will convert /dev/nvme0n1p13 into 3, I think.

We might have better luck with block device major/minor numbers, perhaps, but I did not check if the following is applicable to all block devices:

```
$ stat --format="%t %T" /dev/nvme0n1
103 0
$ stat --format="%t %T" /dev/nvme0n1p1

 1

 1
(After a message from Erickson, I realized that Erickson's suggestion takes the last two characters, not the last character, because awk uses 1-based indexing. Sorry for that.)

I tested it here on a machine with NVMe and the problem happened. But I already have a possible solution:

+device_path=$(realpath $1) && shift
+sfdisk_part_info=$(sfdisk -q -l $device_path)
+devices_nodes=( `echo "$sfdisk_part_info" | awk '$1 == "Device" {i=1; next}; i {print $1}'` )
 
+for device in "${devices_nodes[@]}"; do
+    part_number=( `echo "$device" | awk '{print substr($1, length($1)-1)}' | grep -o '[0-9]\+'`)


What do you think?

Another option:

```
$ cat /sys/block/nvme0n1/nvme0n1p1/partition 
1
$ cat /sys/block/nvme0n1/nvme0n1p2/partition 
2
$ cat /sys/block/nvme0n1/nvme0n1p3/partition 
3
```

However, now we have to cross-reference the block device node (/dev/nvme0n1) to the sysfs directory (/sys/block/nvme0n1).

Yet another option:

```
$ udevadm info /dev/nvme0n1p1 | grep 'E: PARTN='
E: PARTN=1
$ udevadm info /dev/nvme0n1p1 | grep 'E: PARTN='
E: PARTN=1
$ udevadm info /dev/nvme0n1p2 | grep 'E: PARTN='
E: PARTN=2
$ udevadm info /dev/nvme0n1p3 | grep 'E: PARTN='
E: PARTN=3
```

sysinv 2022-11-23 19:44:14.557 2191483 WARNING sysinv.conductor.manager [-] Armada pod is not running and ready. Defer audit.

We still need the audit function to run..

Upgrade tests:
- Script doesn't cause upgrade failure, as expected.
- Couldn't test removal of docker image because of a bug in upgrades where scripts can't call 'system' commands. Warning log recorded as expected.

lgtm

So, Melanie, if you see that similar monkeypatching will be needed for backports time to time, then maybe it's better to backport [1] and [2]. But we need to keep it in mind, that probably we need to backport it along to older stable branches as well.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_collectd/m.message: This line might be the only relevant change, but the other changes make it more consistent.

I'd prefer the previous format because that allows us limit "git blame"
(I mean, for example replacing collectd-server by a different name does not affect the whole line but only that line)

😊

I preferred the old way too, and will change it back in the next patchset. I'm going to explain my POV here anyways so I can maybe reference it in an issue for the Ansible docs.

While debugging, we had reason to suspect that the old way was not working (tasks seemed to apply to one host and not the other), consulted the Ansible docs, and then changed it to this.

In the Ansible Playbook docs[1], we refer to a "hosts line" (never "list") and "the host pattern" (never plural), and it links to the section on "Patterns: targeting hosts and groups"[2], which says "You can use either a comma (,) or a colon (:) to separate a list of hosts" and shows that usage in an example called "Multiple hosts". It gives no examples of other methods to target a list of hosts. I concluded based on this that "the host pattern" is a yaml string only, never a yaml list, thought that was a bit weird and didn't match my memory (but hey, things change!), and so I made this change accordingly. 

Needless to say, it didn't actually solve our problem, and I've since convinced myself that using a yaml list does in fact, still work just fine. 

Patchset 5 coming up

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbook_guide/playbooks_intro.html#playbook-execution
[2] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/inventory_guide/intro_patterns.html
